message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the image and presentation, this patient has psoriasis. The best initial step in management is topical treatments such as corticosteroids and/or vitamin D analogs. Skin biopsy may be performed later if necessary. Oral corticosteroids and methotrexate are reserved for severe cases or if topical treatment is ineffective.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The appearance of the rash is consistent with psoriasis. Topical corticosteroids and/or topical vitamin D analog are the first-line therapy for psoriasis. Skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis if there is uncertainty, while oral corticosteroids and oral methotrexate are reserved for more severe cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image and description suggest the patient has psoriasis. The best initial step in management is topical corticosteroids and/or topical vitamin D analog. Skin biopsy can be done if diagnosis is unclear or in rare cases. Oral corticosteroids and methotrexate may be used for severe cases, but are not typically the first line of treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The picture and the description suggest the patient has psoriasis. The best initial step is to manage it with topical corticosteroids and/or topical vitamin D analog. Skin biopsy may be needed if the diagnosis is uncertain or if the symptoms do not respond to treatment. Oral corticosteroids and methotrexate are reserved for severe cases or cases that do not respond to other treatments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image and description of the rash suggest psoriasis. The best initial step in management is to prescribe topical corticosteroids and/or topical vitamin D analog, as they are effective in reducing inflammation and scaling associated with psoriasis. Skin biopsy may provide a definitive diagnosis but is not necessary at this point. Oral corticosteroids and methotrexate are reserved for more severe cases of psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image and symptoms suggest psoriasis. Topical corticosteroids and/or topical vitamin D analog are the first-line treatment for mild to moderate psoriasis. Skin biopsy may be needed if diagnosis is uncertain, and oral corticosteroids or methotrexate are reserved for more severe cases.

The image shows the classic presentation of psoriasis, which can be managed with topical corticosteroids and/or vitamin D analogs as the best initial step. A skin biopsy would confirm the diagnosis but is not necessary at this point. Oral corticosteroids and methotrexate are reserved for more severe cases.

Topical corticosteroids and/or topical vitamin D analogs are the first-line treatment for mild to moderate psoriasis. Skin biopsy may be done to confirm the diagnosis, but it is not the initial step in management. Oral corticosteroids and methotrexate are reserved for more severe cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image depicts psoriasis, which is commonly treated with topical corticosteroids and/or topical vitamin D analogs as the first-line therapy. Skin biopsy is not necessary for diagnosis and oral corticosteroids and methotrexate are typically reserved for severe cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image and symptoms suggest psoriasis, which is commonly treated with topical corticosteroids and/or topical vitamin D analogs as the initial step. Skin biopsy is not necessary if the diagnosis can be made clinically. Oral corticosteroids and methotrexate are more commonly used for severe cases or when topical treatment is ineffective.
